data.text: The group of natural processes, including weathering, dissolution, abrasion, corrosion, and transportation, by which material is worn away from the earth's surface.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The process of eroding or the condition of being eroded.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: erosion of confidence in the governor; erosion of the value of the dollar.

data.text: The act or operation of eating or gnawing away.
Hence The act of wearing away by any means.
In zoology, the abrasion or wearing away of a surface or margin, as if by gnawing; the state of being erose; the act of eroding.
In geology, the wearing away of rocks by water and other agencies of geological change.
The state of being eaten or worn away; corrosion; canker; ulceration.
The act or operation of eroding or eating away.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: The state of being eaten away; corrosion; canker.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: The wearing away of the earth's surface by any natural process. The chief agent of erosion is running water; minor agents are glaciers, the wind, and waves breaking against the coast.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
